newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Cominco sees LME zinc price heading higher.
newsitem.headline: Cominco sees LME zinc price heading higher.

text.p: Zinc prices are likely to extend their current surging rally, particularly in the second half of this year when supplies become tight, a senior official at Canadian miner Cominco Ltd said on Tuesday.

"We do see a trend higher. I could see another US$100 getting added to the price from the current level without a lot of difficulty," Colin Blyth, managing director of Asia Pacific Cominco Metals pte Ltd, told Reuters in an interview.
Zinc prices surged to a 4-1/2 year high on the London Metal Exchange on Monday and were indicated at a peak of $1,240/242 a tonne before closing $21 up on the day at $1,239.
Blyth said a decline in stocks and rising consumption will fuel further gains in zinc prices.
Cominco expects zinc demand to outstrip supply by around 210,000 tonnes in 1997, while year-end stocks may slide to around 660,000 tonnes from 880,000 tonnes by the end of 1996.
He declined, however, to predict what price level the metal could reach.
"I think there is a very good chance for a price increase further from today's level in the second half," he said.
Blyth added that the thought zinc could consolidate at current levels for the time being.
"I think what you'll go through right now is a period of consolidation. There's no huge increase of physical demand right now," Blyth said.
